ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: General introduction to biocultural anthropology, as well as OBGYN/midwife healthcare on a global level (well, specifically the 'western' world, and Latin America, as that is the Professor's area of expertise). Very good introduction to anatomy, reproductive biology, etc.
I learned about sociocultural and biological approaches to female biology.

This course provided a lot of information about the female body and its experiences throughout a lifetime. This course was extremely empowering and also help me develop skills related to interacting with scientific work.

I learned so much about the female body and her reproductive cycle.   I learned to think critically about the why's and how's human bodies evolved to become what they are.  Most importantly, I developed a curiosity that extend beyond the classroom.
I developed a deeper understanding of evolutionary biology

I learned how to think about concepts in biology for their evolutionary purpose which gave me a deeper understanding. I learned to consider the environmental context of biology and how this creates variation that is itself normal.
Evolutionary biology of womens reproductive lives, ranging from menstruation, conception, pregnancy and childbirth, menopause, and contraception, etc
I about female evolutionary biology through a reproductive framework.

I learned about female biology from several perspectives including evolutionary biology, feminism, and social science perspectives. I learned a lot about the various phases of women's reproductive lives.

This course is AMAZING! The content is important to every subject and is easily the most helpful class to teach useful life skills.  You'll better understand your body and the general human body, and you'll develop a better socio-cultural framework for biological studies.

You also meditate before each class and the course structure/class community will show you what it means for a professor and course to care about your health and learning.

knowledge: basic knowledge of women's reproductive lifetimes
skills: how to critique media articles and have educated conversations about reproductive rights and needs
insights: the importance of recognizing the experience of individuals as well as marginalized communities
I learned more about reproduction and how discussions about reproductive lives differ among different communities.
The ability to think critically and cross-culturally about women's health in a new way.
I gained so much knowledge regarding evolutionary biology and the ecological and biosocial elements of women's health.
Knowledge about the female reproductive life from birth to menopause

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:
Claudia is EXCELLENT. I would take any class with her, and I'm an English major! The syllabus is so excellently balanced to be challenging/engaging while still manageable. A lot of introspective assignments, flexibility, etc. Super well organized for people of all levels of scientific study. Everything you could want in a science credit. 

Weaknesses: 
Hard to get into! Took me several tries and a lot of begging. Good and accessible science credits are SO NECESSARY so Yale should work to make sure that teachers like Claudia can teach multiple sections or teach others how to teach like them so we can have more classes like this.

strengths: the professor; content was very relevant and interesting; discussions were very open and judgement-free
weaknesses: none!
Professor Valeggia is amazing- she made this class one of my favorites.

They are all strengths.  I LOVE Claudia.  She is unique in that she respects the student and creates a collaborative and inclusive learning environment.  She pushes her students to think critically, while engaging with the world and each other.
Strengths is definitely Professor Valeggia. She's amazing
This was an excellent and engaging course. The readings supported lecture material very well and were enjoyable, the class community was outstanding. Overall, am an outstanding course.

This is the best course I have taken at Yale by far! 
Strengths: I learned so much about the female human body and reproductive and women's healthcare across many different cultures. I also learned about the inadequacies of women's healthcare in the US today and many of the problems that need to be addressed still. Professor Valeggia is the best professor and made the space welcoming and inviting. She had us do a 5 min meditation at the start of each class to ground us and prepare us for the class ahead. The final project is really open and creative which allowed for students' to express individual and unique perspectives about what they learned in the course. Students led the discussion each week which provided a myriad of different perspectives as the starting point for each topic. 
Weaknesses: There was a good amount of reading that didn't end up getting discussed because there were so many interesting topics to talk about. This made doing some of the reading a chore because it wasn't discussed at all.

Honestly no weaknesses. Despite being a virtual class this was one of the best classes Ive taken at Yale - the Monday lecture and Wednesday discussion was a good format, I greatly appreciated the 5 min meditation sessions, and the readings and content were interesting!

Strengths: This is one of the best courses I have taken at Yale--Claudia and my peers were wonderful and I felt like I learned so much about female bodies and reproduction. 

Weaknesses: NONE

Dr. V is honestly one of the greatest strengths of this course, she is just a wonderful professor and so understanding. She knows the material like the back of her hand but still values hearing our perspectives and ideas. I don't think there are any weaknesses in this course, I think everyone should take this class.

Strengths: Important coursework, easily relevant to your life, understanding professors, clear assignment due date structure, creative space to take your learning where you want it to go, useful life skills, inclusive to various backgrounds and various methods of learning... and more, it was an amazing course.

Weaknesses: Occasionally, the rubrics for assignments were a bit vague but easily clarified in the many office hours held for the class. No complaints other than that!
this course is amazing! I don't have any weaknesses to report
I really enjoyed having student-led discussions on Wednesday.
I liked our mixed seminar and lecture style, it lent for a lot of engagement. Our class was able to grow very close, even virtually.

This course was incredibly structured-- I can't think of any  glaring weaknesses of the course. A small improvement I would make is that I wish the T&Qs were posted after we learned the lecture material because it was sometimes difficult to approach them with no prior knowledge.
AMAZING COURSE, no weaknesses, if you can get in please take this course!!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Claudia was so understanding about how unexpectedly difficult this semester was and the wide variety of ways students were coping with these obstacles. I thought the formatting of the class was well adapted to virtual learning. Only struggles I had were struggles I had in every class (burnout, zoom fatigue, etc.)
Professor V was so flexible and kind, adapting the assignments to the hard semester
You did great! I think you used to Zoom platform as best as you could.
Having students lead some discussions and keeping lectures as more of a discussion format helped to make the course engaging even in the online setting.
Break out rooms were great to discuss things with our peers.

The emphasis on learning rather than numerical grades as well as the extensions on the T&Qs and other assignments were great ideas/techniques. It really allowed me to focus on the material than being concerned about deadlines.
I thought the Monday lecture and Wednesday seminar format worked very well and breakout rooms helped my connect with my peers.

On Monday, the lecture was recorded and the notes were always posted. This was very useful in reviewing tough information or clarifying any course material confusion.


Wednesdays were live seminars in small and large groups, this was great and probably the best format of any of my online courses so far. Students led the discussions each week and so you always felt comfortable asking questions or sharing your thoughts.
totally fine
I really enjoyed having discussions in small break-out rooms.
Yes! Although, I wish that there were better methods of participating in the large group because it always felt like a few of the same voices would dominate the conversation.
All of the practices were great!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. If you can get in, take it 100%
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student if they are interested in learning about female reproduction through an evolutionary lens.
YES! If you are able to get a spot in the class, you MUST take it
YES
Yes, yes, yes.  Take it!

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone remotely interested in the topic. I thought I knew a lot about women's reproduction going in, but I still learned a ton. Plus, Claudia is absolutely one of the kindest, most accessible, and most clear professors at Yale. Take it if you can get in!
Yes absolutely loved this course!

I would recommend this course to other Yale students, especially in the biology major. The course is well organized, facilitates thinking in new ways, and provides an enriching community and learning environement.
Absolutely! This is an amazing course, you MUST take this course if you can get off the lottery.
Absolutely! One of the best classes Ive taken at Yale. Such an eye-opening course.
I would 100% recommend this course to another student for the professor alone. TAKE IT if you have the chance!
Yes! My favorite class I've taken at Yale.

ABSOLUTELY! Take this class to learn about yourself, develop real-life skills, apply a cultural framework to your typical science class, and experience an amazing professor who prioritizes your health alongside your learning.

Absolutely!! Even as an online class, this course was amazing! I challenged many preconceived notions I held about female bodies, gender stereotypes, and gendered processes. I really got to know the other students in the class as well as my own body. The class environment was so warm and inviting, and I feel like I "walked out" of the class with so much knowledge and many new connections. Even if you're just looking to learn a bit more about menstruation or birth control or pregnancy, you will not regret this class. I am not a STEM-oriented person, and even though a few of the readings might have been confusing, the assignments were definitely doable, and for the final project, Dr. V allowed us to choose our own topics and mediums. Definitely a highlight of the semester!

YES!!!! Every human person should take this course. If the content is relevant your biology, take it to learn more about yourself. If the content is not applicable to your biology, take it to learn the nuances and sensitivity that these conversations require. Educate yourself so that you can go out in the world and help contribute to a society that is open and understanding to the lives of female-bodied people.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students regardless of their intended major.
Yes - it was very engaging to learn about women's health issues and analyze our current medical system.
Absolutely! 10/10 would recommend
Yes!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual leminar, one day of lecture, one day of discussion (around 20 students so a large seminar/small lecture)
virtual "leminar" (lecture on Monday, seminar discussion on Wednesday)
This course included lecture and discussion sections. Both were virtual this semester.
Mix of virtual lecture and virtual seminar
lecture and seminar format
This course is a leminar with one day of class each week devoted to lecture and one week devoted to seminar discussion.
Live virtual lecture and live virtual seminar

Class had a really interesting format that I really enjoyed. The first class of the week was a traditional lecture and the second class of the week was a group discussion class where we could collaboratively share.
leminar
Each week, we had one day with lectures and one day with student-led discussions about the lectures.
monday: recorded lecture, wednesday: seminar style
It was a combination of a live virtual lecture and a virtual seminar.
Lecture and seminar.
This was a virtual seminar with both lecture and conversational components.
It was all virtual!
